docs.title: Introductory Tutorials
docs.text: • David O'Toole Org tutorial

docs.title: Headings
docs.text:
***** Heading Level 1
****** Heading Level 2
******* Heading Level 3
******** Heading Level 4
etc.
  • Headings can be inserted at the same level by Alt + Enter from end of line.
  • Headings can be rearranged up or down by Alt + ↑/↓.
  • Headings can be changed to another level by Alt + ←/→.

docs.title: Lists
docs.text:
- Item 1
- Item 2
  • Lists are very similar to headings. The shortcuts for rearranging heading above can also be used for rearranging lists.
  • List style can be changed by Shift + ←/→.

docs.title: Commonly-used symbols
docs.text:
Insert the following into your .emacs file:

;; Set up keyboard shortcuts for math symbols
;; http://ergoemacs.org/emacs/emacs_n_unicode.html
(define-key key-translation-map (kbd "<f9> a") (kbd "α"))
(define-key key-translation-map (kbd "<f9> b") (kbd "β"))
(define-key key-translation-map (kbd "<f9> d") (kbd "δ"))
(define-key key-translation-map (kbd "<f9> D") (kbd "Δ"))
(define-key key-translation-map (kbd "<f9> ul") (kbd "µl"))
(define-key key-translation-map (kbd "<f9> ug") (kbd "µg"))
(define-key key-translation-map (kbd "<f9> ->") (kbd "→"))
(define-key key-translation-map (kbd "<f9> <-") (kbd "←"))

Then you can hit F9 and the key above to insert the corresponding symbol.

docs.title: Font styling
docs.text:
*bold*
/italic/, /genesymbol/
_underline_
=verbatim=, =inlinecode=

docs.title: Hyperlinks
docs.text:
[[http://www.linkaddress.com][Link Text]]

If you want the hyperlink to be displayed as the address itself:

[[http://www.linkaddress.com]]

docs.title: Tables
docs.text:
| Col 1  | Col 2  | Col 3  |
|--------+--------+--------|
| Data 1 | Data 2 | Data 3 |
| Data 4 | Data 5 | Data 6 |

Note that the tables are smart:

  • Tab will introduce a new column.
  • Enter will introduce new now.
  • |- followed by Tab will introduce the full line between header and first row.

docs.title: Automatic timestamps
docs.text:
• Ctrl-C → Shift-1 will introduce date stamp.
  • Ctrl-U → Ctrl-C → Shift-1 will introduce date with time stamp.

docs.title: TODO items
docs.text: You can make any heading into a TODO item by Shift + →. Pressing this again, will cycle the TODO state to WAITING, DONE etc.

docs.title: Deadlines and Scheduling
docs.text:
• Ctrl + c → Ctrl + s from a headline will insert a schedule date for that heading.
  • Ctrl + c → Ctrl + d from a headline will insert a deadline date for that heading.

docs.title: Figures
docs.text:
You can insert links to images with [[file:PATH_TO_IMAGE] and then display them within the Org mode buffer with the command M-x org-display-inline-images.

This will display the image in its full size (usually way too large), so you can either resize the image in Inkscape, Gimp etc. before linking, or add some code to .emacs to set a default display width. The second option is OS-specifc.

docs.title: Source code
docs.text:
#+BEGIN_SRC

Source code here

#+END_SRC

Keyboard shortcut is <s → Tab.

You can also get language-specific syntax highlighting when you export Org mode files to HTML or Latex. Look at Rasi's Emacs configuration file: https://github.com/rasilab/rasi_xps15_config/blob/master/emacs#L225-L244 for how to do this.

docs.title: Latex
docs.text:
Most latex syntax can be used without any special notation in Org mode. This is particularly useful for fine control over figure placements, journal-specific environments etc.

To insert latex headers, do

#+LATEX_HEADER: \usepackage{amsmath}

docs.title: Insert table of contents into your Org mode file
docs.text:
It is really useful to have a Table of Contents for Org files that you frequently view on Github.

You can install TOC-Org package so that every time you save your Org file, a Table of Contents is automatically generated and updated.

To install this package, do M-x package-install and enter toc-org.

Then insert a :TOC: tag to the first headline in the Org file by C-c C-q. Look at the Raw code for this file as an example.

The above TOC was generated automatically using the TOC-Org package.

docs.title: Work with rectangular regions
docs.text:
Rectangular cut, copy, paste is useful for working with tabular data.

You can select rectangular regions by setting a mark at one diagonal using C-SPC, and then going to the other diagonal point of the rectangle.

C-x r k will cut the rectangular region.

C-x r y will paste the rectangular region.

For more information, see https://www.emacswiki.org/emacs/RectangleCommands.

docs.title: Advanced Org mode notes
docs.text:
• How to take notes efficiently in Org mode? Useful for learning about org-refile and org-capture.
  • The Org mode syntax as parsed by Emacs elisp is defined here.

docs.title: Introduction to elisp
docs.text:
• lists are made of cons cells.
  • Each cons cell is made of a car (key) and cdr (value) in the case of an associative list, alist.
  • In a typical list, the car points to the next cons cell.
(defun hello (someone)
    "Say hello to SOMEONE via M-x hello."
    (interactive "sWho do you want to say hello to? ")
    (message "Hello %s!" someone))

hello

(defun foo (&optional print-message)
       (interactive "p")
       (when print-message
         (message "foo")))

foo

(let ((words))
  (save-excursion
    (goto-char 0)
    (while (re-search-forward "\\w+" (point-max) t)
      (let ((word (match-string-no-properties 0)))
        (cl-incf (cdr (or (assoc word words)
                          (first (push (cons word 0) words)))))))
    (reverse (sort words (lambda (a b) (< (cdr a) (cdr b)))))))

docs.title: How to add a new bibliography style file
docs.text:
.bst files are in ~/lib/texlive/2018/texmf-dist/bibtex/bst/.

After adding files at the above location, you need to update the cache by running texhash ~/lib/texlive/2018/texmf-dist from the command line. If successful, everything in that folder should be in the 'path' for bibtex.

You can check that your file is properly registered with kpsewhich:

kpsewhich your-bibtex-file.bst

This should produce the full path name to your bst. If so, then you're all set.

Reference

docs.title: Writing
docs.text:
• Lab notebook
  • Figures
  • Presentations
  • Papers
  • Grant applications

docs.title: Links
docs.text:
• Weitzlab Guide to Good Paper Writing
  • Hoffman lab writing style guide
  • How to write a great science paper

docs.title: Presentation formatting
docs.text:
1. Slide headings should be centered and font size 36, Helvetica or Arial
  2. All major phrases and words in the slide that you want the audience to see should be between 20pt and 24pt.
  3. Axis tick labels and minor details should be 18pt.
  4. No text should have font size <18pt. If you want to de-emphasize text that is less important, change the text color from black to grey. If you want to emphasize text, make it bold or use a text box around.
  5. Design slides in Inkscape.
  6. Make all text editable by exporting figures as PDFs from R or Python.
  7. All schematics should be made as scalable vector graphics rather than bitmap images so that they can be used by others in the lab.

docs.title: Logistics for fellowship applications
docs.text:
• Send a draft of the Specific Aims section to Rasi at least 4 weeks before deadline, but no later than 3 weeks before deadline.
  • Send a draft of the full proposal to Rasi at least 2 weeks before deadline.
  • All fellowship applications have to be approved by Fred Hutch irrespective of whether the prospective funder needs institutional approval. Please contact our lab's research administrator at least 1 month before the deadline to let them know that you will be applying.

docs.title: Start with the Specific Aims section
docs.text:
• To outline the aims, add a sentence or two to each of the questions:
    1. Who are the target audience?
    2. What is the problem?
    3. What is known?
    4. What is not known?
    5. What is the solution you are proposing?
    6. What are you bringing that is unique (‘Innovation’)?
    7. What is the expected impact (‘So what?’)?
    8. What are the key resources / personnel that you need?
  • Run the above (usually this is ‘Specific Aims’) by Rasi, lab members, or other colleagues.

docs.title: Convert Specific Aims into an outline
docs.text:
• Convert the Specific Aims to an outline in the format required by the funding agency. These are usually the ‘Significance’, ‘Innovation’, ‘Approach’ sections of NIH grants.
  • Each Aim can be subdivided into multiple sub-aims in the Approach section.
  • Each sub-aim should have a Rationale, Method, Expected Outcome, Alternate Plans section.

docs.title: Expand the outline
docs.text:
• Use short sentences without conjunctions or multiple clauses. Whenever possible, break longer sentences into multiple short sentences.
  • Proofread and get it reviewed by your lab members and a few outside colleagues.

docs.title: Writing Background or Significance
docs.text:
Your Background or Significance section should address 3 points:

  1. Why is the problem you are studying important and interesting?
  2. What are the existing gaps in our knowledge or limitations of current approaches to study the problem?
  3. How is your approach going to address the above gap.

Your background should not contain information that is unrelated to your project. Ask yourself if a background sentence will help the reader understand your research design or outcome. If it doesn't, remove the sentence.
